thread.title: Shock approaching deal with AFL to keep name
thread.title_full: Shock approaching deal with AFL to keep name

title: Shock approaching deal with AFL to keep name
text:
Facebook Email Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest Shock approaching deal with AFL to keep name The Spokane Shock are closing in on a deal with the AFL to retain the rights to the team name. Post to Facebook Shock approaching deal with AFL to keep name The Spokane Shock are closing in on a deal with the AFL to retain the rights to the team name.   KREM.com: http://on.krem.com/1LrFwc2   Join the Conversation To   Shock approaching deal with AFL to keep name The Spokane Shock organization is nearing a deal with the AFL to retain its team name and all associated trademarks as the squad moves to the IFL. Evan Closky, KREM2 Sports Reporter 12:11 a.m. PDT October 13, 2015 The Spokane Shock are closing in on a deal with the AFL to retain the rights to the team name. (Photo: Spokane Shock) CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
The Spokane Shock are nearing a deal with the Arena Football League to retain the rights to all Spokane Shock trademarks. 
The organization told KREM2 "It sounds like we have an agreement in principle. Just trying to get everything on paper and final." 
The big stir came Monday afternoon when the AFL released this statement: 
The Arena Football League has been in discussions with the Spokane Shock about allowing them to continue using the Shock name and trademarks. The rights to all Spokane Shock trademarks and logos are owned by the AFL and there have been earnest attempts to reach an agreement for the acquisition of those marks. Unfortunately, those attempts have not come to fruition and the League will retain the rights to the Spokane Shock name. The League intends to have a presence in the State of Washington again in the near future. 
The organization told KREM2 the ownership group had a conference call with the league office shortly after that statement was released to get more information and clarity on the matter. The team was a bit surprised by the league's statement, but all issues seem to be figured out. 
The first game in the IFL kicks off on February 27 at Spokane Arena. Expect the Tri-Cities Fever to take on the Spokane Shock. Read or Share this story: http://on.krem.com/1LrFwc2 TOP VIDEOS
